The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Fitea will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Musaka SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Mme Mariam  est mariée  et mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 14ans et le moins âgé a 11ans. Tous vont  à l’école. Elle a 04 personnes en charge.

Elle vend des pagnes et des habits pour enfants depuis 09ans. Elle s’approvisionne  au marché du secteur 10 en ville. Ses clients sont  les gens des différents quartiers.

Elle veut  s’acheter  04 paquets d’habits pour enfants.

 Avec  ses bénéfices, elle améliore son activité. Elle ambitionne  pouvoir aider son mari à payer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mariam is married and mother to two children. The oldest is 14 and the youngest 11 years old. They both go to school. She has four people under her care.

She has been selling loincloths and children's clothing for nine years. She buys her supplies at the market of sector 10 in town. Her clients are from the different neighborhoods.

She wants to buy four bundles of children's clothing.

With her profits, she plans to improve her business. Her goal is to be able to help her husband to pay for her children's schooling.

loans.use: to buy four bundles of children's clothing.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy more cattle

loans.name: Fadel

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 41 years old, married and has six children.

Fadel is a blacksmith.  He has owned a workshop since 2005, where he makes windows and doors. He has a deep understanding of local consumer needs and has sufficient experience in this field. He has a good reputation and is well-known in his area.

Fadel decided to apply for a $3000 loan in order to pay the annual rent for his workshop and to add more inventories. He is aiming to gain more profits to offer him the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: pay workshop rent and and add inventory

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Chanthou (in the photo) and her husband, Sophea, 20, live along National Road Number One, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2004 and have one daughter.

Chanthou and her husband have full-time employment in the same company. She is now in the process of building a new house to live in, but the house is not finished yet because Chanthou lacks some money to finish it.   Hence, she decided to ask for a loan of $500 to make the finishes.

loans.use: finish building her house

loans.name: Denis

texts.en: Denis is a hardworking business man, aged 31. He is married and blessed with a four-year-old child who is in school. For the last three years, he has been working as a photographer to earn a living. He also runs a salon business to supplement his income. Denis has been able to retain his business because of a good reputation with his customers. In the next 5 years, he wants to open another outlet for his business. He expresses gratitude to Faulu Kenya for training him on good customer care. With 20,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to buy a camera.

loans.use: buy a camera

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 36-year-old Lebanese single man living on his own. Like many men his age, Bassam is looking to have his own family and children.

After being involved for 15 years in repairing computers, he decided to open his own computer workshop and maintenance in 2009. 

Today he is asking to borrow $2,700 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase an added quantity of spare parts and computer accessories in order to expand his business, acquire more benefits and satisfy his customers. 

In the future, he plans to have his own computer shop.

loans.use: to purchase an added quantity of spare parts and computer accessories.

loans.name: Meltu

texts.en:
Meltu is a 39-year-old man, married to Onci, a 30-year-old lady. They are blessed with five children namely: Veron, 13, in the 2nd grade of Senior High School; Angke, 10; Ariel, 8; Tiara, 6, (the three of them are at Primary School) and Aurelia, 3.

Meltu has been running a kiosk business for almost two years. He sells various household needs, such as food, snacks, cigarettes, bath soap, detergent, shampoo, and some cakes cooked by his wife. In addition to running a kiosk business, Meltu can also repair bicycles so sometimes he uses his skill to generate more income.

Meltu is planning to complete the business stock in his kiosk as demanded by the customers. In view of this opportunity, Meltu is requesting a loan of IDR 4,000,000 from TLM to purchasr various items such as soft drinks, snacks, etc. Meltu is expecting that the loan applications will be approved by TLM soon.

loans.use: to purchase various items such as soft drinks, snacks, etc.

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Sophea (pictured above), age 31, is a garment worker. Her husband, Thol, age 30, is a construction worker. They have been married since 2002 and have two young children -- one son and one daughter.  The family lives in the area surrounding Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sophea is asking for her first loan of $250 to add to her own money to buy a new motorbike for her husband to ride to work. Because his old motorbike breaks very often, it is costly to repair and uses more gasoline than newer motorbikes.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas is married and blessed with three children who are in school. For the last ten years, she has been running a beauty salon business to bring up her family. She also does farming to increase her income. Dorcas has employed two people to assist her to manage her business. She has been able to retain her business because of a good reputation with her customers.  In the next 5 years, she plans to establish a wholesale business. Dorcas has requested for a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to buy hair braids and hair chemicals.

loans.use: buy hair braids and hair chemicals

loans.name: Bidii Women Group

texts.en:
Patrick is the facilitator of the Bidii Women group. Patrick and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Patrick takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Patrick had a very good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Patrick was only able to harvest 4 ½ bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Patrick and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Patrick will educate his children and build a house in future.

In 2012, the members of Bidii Women group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Patrick is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kimatullo

texts.ru: Киматулло житель района Дангары. Ему 44 года. Женат. Имеет двоих детей. Более 15 лет занимается торговлей фруктов и овощей. Кредит берет для закупа овощей и фруктов.
texts.en: Kimatullo is a resident of the Dangara region. He is 44 years old, married and has two children. He has been selling fruits and vegetables for more than fifteen years. He is taking out the loan to buy carrots, onions, apples and pomegranates.

loans.use: to buy carrots, onions, apples and pomegranates.

loans.name: Riffat Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Riffat is a 32-years-old woman. She is married and lives with her family, a husband and four daughters who are 14, 12, 9 and 4 years old.  

Riffat’s days are focused on making progress with her business. She is involved in sewing & embroidery work.  Her work is home based. She crafts beautiful embroidery designs on clothes and sews them with perfect measurement. Her excellent skills enable her to receive good orders from her clients and she generates good revenue from them.   Her husband’s economic mainstay is selling construction supplies. He also knows construction work and worked as a constructor for many people. He has been operating his business for over 10 years and has a  good clientele.  He is well-known in his business.   

Riffat is requesting for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. He intends to use the loan to  purchase construction supplies such as ladders, bamboos, etc. for his business.   She hopes that her husband will grow the business more and improve the quality of service after the loan investment.

loans.use: buy construction supplies

loans.name: Kun

texts.en:
Kun resides in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. Kun sells leaf roofs. The family is also assisted by her son, who is employed at the factory. 

Kun is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to pay her son’s marriage. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to pay for her son's marriage.

loans.name: Evalyne

texts.en:
Evalyne is married and blessed with two children who are in school. She has been selling clothes for the last thirteen years to support her family. She also does farming to increase her income. She has employed one person to assist her manage the business. 

Evalyne has been able to retain her business because of her good reputation with her customers. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting for a loan of 80,000 Kenyan shillings to add to her stock of clothes for resale. In the next 5 years, she wants to expand her business.

loans.use: buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Yunus

texts.en:
Yunus is a 40-year-old man and is married to Ranti, a 34-year-old lady. From their marriage, they are blessed four children. The children are: Reinaldi, 16, studying at the 1st grade of Senior High School; Desriani, 13, studying at the 1st grade of Junior High School; Saimon, 10, and Arnoldino, 8, studying at Elementary school.

In order to cover his family's living expenses, Yunus worked in construction but the income he generated was unstable since it depended on the project offered. Yunus then initiated a kiosk business to generate more income. He sells daily basic items, mainly rice and the other items such as soft drinks, cooking oil, bath soap, detergent, eggs, instant noodles, etc. 

Yunus plans to get extra income from the business by purchasing a ton of rice and reselling it at his kiosk, but he does not have enough capital to do so. Therefore he is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 5,000,000. Yunus is hoping that TLM will be willing to help him in improving his business.

loans.use: to purchase a ton of rice.

loans.name: Kananachi B Group

texts.en:
Antony is the facilitator of the Kananachi B group. Antony and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Antony takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Antony had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Antony was only able to harvest 2½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Antony and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Antony will educate his children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Kananachi B group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Benendeta

texts.en:
Benendeta is a focused business woman. She is 37 years old, single, and blessed with three children who are in school. She has been running a cereal shop for the last ten years to support her family. She also farms to earn more income. 

Benendeta is requesting a loan of 100,000 Kenyan shillings to buy maize, beans, and peas for resale. She describes her business as busy, since her customers are the local residents. In the next 5 years, she plans to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to buy maize, beans, and peas.

loans.name: Dul

texts.en:
Mrs. Dul is a 47-year-old married woman and has 2 single children. She earns a living by cultivating rice and vegetable crops. She earns $1.50 per day from this business, while her husband earns approximately $5.00 by working as a construction laborer. 

Mrs. Dul would like to borrow $1000 to prepare a wedding party for her older daughter's upcoming marriage. In the future, she plans to own a store near a local school and sell products that appeal to students.

loans.use: to prepare a wedding party for her older daughter.

loans.name: Jean Nepomscene

texts.en:
Jean Nepomscene is 30 years old and is married with four children between the ages 6 and 13 years old. He sells clothes, and his business is well organized. Jean Nepomscene has five years of experience in this business and employs one person to help him.

Jean Nepomscene has requested a loan from Kiva lender VFC in order to purchase more clothes to sell. With the profit made possible by the loan, Jean Nepomscene will reinvest in his business and build his own house from which to run his business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a 26-year-old single man. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. He has been running a tailoring business and selling clothes to make a living. He also raises livestock to supplement his income. 

Since Francis joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access loans to boost his business. In the next 5 years, he plans to open another clothing outlet.   He has requested a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to add to his stock of fabric for making clothes. Francis dreams of buying a piece of land.

loans.use: to add to his stock of fabric.

loans.name: Tugumane Group

texts.fr:
Joselyne est une commerçante âgée de 27 ans qui habite la localité de Rutegama de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle est vendeuse de bière locale depuis 9 ans, un métier qu’elle a commencé alors qu’elle était cultivatrice. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6 è année primaire. Elle est mariée à Abraham, lui aussi commerçant de bière industrielle et ont ensemble 6 enfants dont 3 étudient.
Son  crédit Kiva de 120,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient va lui permettre d’augmenter son capital pour acheter une grande quantité de bière locale  à revendre afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies 
Elle est membre du groupe communautaire TUGUMANE
texts.en:
Joselyne is a 27-year-old shopkeeper who lives in the village of Rutegama in the province of Gitega in the middle of the country. She has been selling local beer for nine years, a profession which she started when she was a farmer. She went to school until the sixth year of primary school. She is married to Abraham, who is also a shopkeeper of industrial beer. They have six children together of whom three go to school. 

Her loan of 120,000 Burundian francs will help her to increase her capital to buy a large quantity of local beer to resell, in order to make large profits and increase her savings. 

She is a member of the community group Tugumane.

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy a large quantity of local beer to resell, in order to make large profits and increase her savings.

loans.name: Lydia's Group

texts.en:
Lydia's group comprises three hard-working women. Lydia is 21 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luweero region of Uganda. For the past two years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells mobile phones. 

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 400,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy mobile phones for resale and will help Lydia to generate greater profits and buy food to feed her family. Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has improved Lydia's prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy mobile phones for resale.

loans.name: Maytham

texts.en:
This borrower, Maytham, is from Iraq. He is 40 years old, married, and has four children.

Maytham is a carpenter; in 2007 he decided to open his own workshop. He makes bedrooms sets and other furniture. He has sufficient experience in this field and a good reputation. He is well known in his area.

He decided to apply for a $3000 loan in order to purchase a wood-working machine. He aims to gain more profits and thus the opportunity to provide a better life for his family as a whole.

loans.use: to purchase a wood-working machine.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 26-year-old single man. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. He has been selling shoes for the last two years to make a living. He also raises livestock to earn extra income. 

Simon has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to buy shoes for resale. In the next 5 years, he wants to establish a wholesale business. Simon dreams of becoming more financially stable in the future, and, thanks to Faulu Kenya, he has become more business-oriented.

loans.use: to buy shoes for sale.

loans.name: Djumakan

texts.ru:
Джумакан родилась в селе Партсъезд (Панфиловский район, Чуйская обл., Кыргызская Республика). Джумакан выросла в большой семье с тремя братьями и двумя сестрами, родители были простыми рабочими.  После окончания школы Джумакан помогала семье по хозяйству и с детства получила большой опыт в работе с домашней живностью и полеводством. Основным источником дохода семьи было выращивание свеклы, и о дальнейшем получении образования  в то время не могло быть и речи. Выйдя замуж за своего односельчанина, молодая семья стала трудится на поле, также выращивая свеклу. Жить в родном селе, где не было работы, где все люди занимались только разведением живности и выращиванием свеклы становилось все трудней и трудней, земли не хватало для всех семей, а у Джумакан к тому времени подрастали дети. Вот так в один день Джумакан с мужем решились попросить у родителей супруга одну из трех дойных коров, ставшей первым вкладом в животноводческий бизнес молодой семьи. Получив корову, семья начала сдавать молоко, муж Джумакан устроился в колхоз чабаном, молодая семья с двумя маленькими детьми жила в маленькой комнатке, которую выделил колхоз. За 5 лет упорного труда, семья собрала деньги на покупку дома и приобрела маленькую времянку. Джумакан с мужем воспитали двух замечательных детей, женили их и стали бабушкой и дедушкой. В поисках средств к существованию, дети Джумакан уехали в Россюи на заработки, оставив им на воспитание трех внуков -  полутора, двух и трех лет.
Сегодня, для того, чтобы прокормить свою семью, Джумакан сдает молоко от двух дойных коров и получает около 3,000 сом (KGS) ежемесячно плюс ее пенсия в 2,500 сом позволяет покрывать ежедневные расходы на детей. Также, Джумакан откармливает двух бычков и планирует закупить дополнительно скот для откорма и перепродажи, так как это достаточно прибыльно. Именно для этой цели, Джумакан обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме  130,000 сом (KGS) на покупку бычков. Доходы она планирует вложить дальнейшее приумножение поголовья скота,  а в будущем – мечтает развить свою ферму.
texts.en:
Djumakan born in the village Partsyezd (in the Panfilov district, Chui region of the Kyrgyz Republic). Djumakan grew up in a big family with three brothers and two sisters. Her parents were ordinary workers. After graduating from high school, Djumakan helped the family on the farm and since childhood she has had tremendous experience working with domestic livestock and crops. The family's main source of income was growing beets, and there was no question of her having access to higher education. She married a fellow villager, and the young family began working in the fields, planting beets. 

Living in her home village became harder and harder.  There was no work--all of them men could only work farming poultry and sugar beets, and by the time Djumakan started raising children there was not enough land for all of the families in the village.  One day, she and her husband asked Djumakan's parents for one of their three milk cows. That became the beginning of the family's livestock business. 

Since they had a cow, the family began to receive milk.  Djumakan's husband got a job as a shepherd.  The young family with two young children lived in a small room, which had been allocated to them by the collective farm. For five years, they worked hard and saved money to buy a house with a small outhouse. Djumakan and her husband raised two wonderful children, married them off, and become grandparents. 

Djumakan's children left to work in Russia and left her to raise her three grandchildren, aged one and a half, two, and three years old. Today, in order to feed their family, Djumakan keeps two dairy cows and receives about 3,000 som a month from the milk, plus her monthly pension of 2,500 som. This pays for the children's expenses. Also, Djumakan is fattening two steers and plans to purchase additional cattle for fattening and resale, since it is profitable. To do this, she contacted Bai-Tushum and Partners for a loan of 130,000 som (KGS) to buy calves. She is planning to invest her profit into more livestock and she dreams of further expanding her farm.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Wendmalgkondo Group

texts.fr:
Mme JOSEPHINE  est la représentante du groupe WENDMALGKONDO. Elle est mariée  et mère de 07 enfants. Le plus âgé a 35ans et le moins âgé a 18ans. 04  vont à l’école. Elle a 06 personnes en charge.

Elle vend du jus depuis  05ans. Elle s’approvisionne dans les différentes provinces du BURKINA .Ses clients sont  les élèves et les voisins.

Elle veut  s’acheter  01 sac de sucre, 01 balle de sachets pour le conditionnement, 03 douzaines d’arome et 01 sac de bissaps pour la fabrication du jus.

 Elle épargne  ses bénéfices  afin d’améliorer son activité en achetant un réfrigérateur. Elle ambitionne  aider son mari pour la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Josephine is the representative of the Wendmalgkondo group. She is married with seven children; the eldest is 35 and the youngest is 18 years old. Four of the children go to school, and she cares for six persons as dependents.

She has been selling juice for the past five years. She resupplies in the different provinces of Burkina Faso. Her customers are students and neighbors.

She wants to buy one bag of sugar, one bale of plastic bags for packaging, three dozen flasks of aromas and one bag of hibiscus for juicing.

She puts her profits into savings so that she can buy a refrigerator and improve her business activity. Her aim is to help her husband manage the children's tuition costs.

loans.use: buy one bag of sugar, one bale of plastic bags for packaging, three dozen flasks of aromas and one bag of hibiscus for juicing

loans.name: Njete Women Group

texts.en:
George is the facilitator of the Njete Women group. George and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to George and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

George takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food to ensure food security for his family and later educate his children. In the recent 2011 season, George had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, George was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, George will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Njete Women group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows George with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables to resell and purchase a refrigerator for frozen food.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is a 28-year-old, hardworking, single business man. For the last eight years, he has been running a grocery business to make a living. He has employed one person to assist him in managing the business. James has been able to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers. 

James is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy tomatoes and potatoes for resale. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes and potatoes for sale.

loans.name: Tsolak

texts.en: Tsolak is from the village of Kamo in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is married with two sons (seventeen and nineteen years old).  Tsolak has a high school education and has been farming for the past ten years.  He considers himself a sociable person and dreams of renovating the family home.  As his financial means are insufficient, he has turned to microfinance to fund his business.  He is looking for a loan to purchase animal feed.  He expects this investment to increase the family income and allow him to save some money.  This is his first microfinance loan and he is pleased with the services.  He enjoys being a self-employed entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase animal feed

loans.name: Kewa Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kewa SHG Group in Western Kenya! Everlyne is the facilitator of the Kewa SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Everlyne  takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Everlyne had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Everlyne was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Everlyne  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Everlyne will educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Kewa SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 35-year-old, hardworking businessman. He is married and blessed with two children, one of whom is in school. He has been selling sand for the last four years to support his family. Moses has been able to retain his business because of his good reputation with his customers. 

Moses is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy sand for resale. In the next 5 years, he plans to open another business outlet.

loans.use: to buy sand.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional charcoal for her shop.

loans.name: Misha

texts.en:
Misha is from the village of Ashotck in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Ashotck is his birthplace and he is proud of his village.  He hopes to live there permanently.  Misha is married with two children: a twenty-three-year-old daughter and an eighteen-year-old son.  Misha has been engaged in farming since 1988.  He hopes to increase his income to support his children’s higher education.  He has been using the services of microfinance for three years and is pleased with the services and the credit disbursement process.  This year, he would like another loan to purchase livestock.  With this new loan, Misha expects the family income to increase by 15%.  This loan is about 40% of the capital he has already invested in his business.


About the Field Partner – AREGAK Universal Credit Organization
In the fall of 1997, United Methodist Committee on Relief (UMCOR) established the AREGAK microfinance program, with the purpose to create economic opportunities for low income people who have no or limited access to the formal financial sources, especially in the remote rural areas. The microfinance program rapidly became one of the largest MFI in Armenia in terms of number of active clients and portfolio size.

In March of 2006, AREGAK UCO was registered as a Universal Credit Organization, structured as a Closed Joint Stock Company with UMCOR as the sole shareholder.
Today, AREGAK UCO provides a broad range of financial services to the population without compromising the social aspects of its mission and continues initiatives geared toward the fulfillment of its ethical principles

Vision Statement
To be the most dynamic and ethical financial institution in Armenia and Nagorno Karabagh.

Mission Statement
AREGAK supports the economic development of small and medium entrepreneurs with high quality, accessible and reliable financial services.

AREGAK UCO’s Ethical Principles
1. Integrity and Excellence
We deliver on our promises
We are honest and transparent in everything we do
We provide excellent customer service
2. Respect and Inclusion
Our leadership, workforce and decision-making reflect and respect the diversity of customers and communities we serve.
We value all employees, investing in their personal and professional growth.
3. Innovation
We develop new processes and systems to improve efficiency
We create value added new products to enhance economic opportunities

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Orsmak

texts.en:
Orsmak is 22 years old, and her husband, Sothea, is 27 years old. They live in a village approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  They have been married since 2007 and have one young daughter. 

Orsmak and her husband sell rice and soft drinks from their home. They also grow rice during the rice farming season. 

Orsmak is applying for a loan in the amount of $500 to buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide for her rice farming business.

In the photo, Orsmak and her husband and young daughter are at home.

loans.use: to buy seed, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain her rice farm.

loans.name: Nicholus

texts.en: Nicholus is married and blessed with five children - all of whom attend school. He has been practicing dairy farming to support his family. He also does crop farming to supplement his income. His hard work and determination has helped him to retain his business. He has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan Shillings to buy animal feed and seeds. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy animal feed and seeds.

loans.name: Von

texts.en:
Mr. Von, 37, is the father of 3 children. With his team, he works as a construction worker in a variety of locations, which provides him with nonstop work to do. He is able to earn in the neighborhood of $4.50 a day. He has tried very hard to support his children because he wants them to pursue a high standard of living and have a bright future. 

With this loan amount, he will purchase a second-hand motorcycle that will be used for both work and family transportation. In the future, he intends to open a general store so his wife can sell a variety of products from his house.

loans.use: to purchase a second-hand motorcycle.

loans.name: Bayandelger

texts.en:
Bayandelger is a 29-year-old man who operates a clothing retail stall at a local market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Aside from his business at the market, he works as an excavator specialist at Hera Investment Co., Ltd., a company that supplies heavy machinery and equipment. As Bayandelger is often called out of town, his wife runs their clothing business. They sell women’s clothing imported from Beijing, China. 

Bayandelger is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to purchase more clothing for this fall. He is a trusted client of Transcapital Company, Ltd., and he always pays his loans successfully and on time.  

Bayandelger has been saving his earnings with the intention of moving into an apartment and improving his and his wife's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for sale.

loans.name: Noeline

texts.en:
Noeline is 36 years old, married, and has five children between the ages of 3 and 15. Her business is well organized. Noeline operates a shop where she sells items such as soap, water, juice, body lotion, etc. She has four years of experience and employs one person to help her.

Noeline has requested a loan from Kiva lender Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more soap, water, juice, body lotion, rice, sugar, and Irish potatoes to sell. With her profit, Noeline will reinvest in her business and save for her future.

loans.use: To purchase more soap, water, juice, body lotion, etc.

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en: Tereza is from the village of Zuygaghbyur in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Zuygaghbyur is a beautiful place with alpine meadows and pastures ideal for livestock farming.  Tereza is a teacher by training but due to difficult economic times, she has been working as a farmer for the past ten years.  She considers herself a hardworking and honest person.  Tereza is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  She expects this investment to increase her income by 15%.  She dreams of buying additional land and expanding her business.  Tereza likes living in Zuygaghbyur and is surrounded by her close relatives.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en: Samwel is a single man aged 24. For the last two years, he has been operating a motorbike transport business to make a living. He has employed one person to assist him to manage the business. He expresses gratitude to Faulu Kenya for training him on good customer care. He has requested for a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings to buy a motorbike. In the next 5 years, he plans to transform his business from a motorbike to van transport business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Amani W G Group

texts.en:
Nalulwe is the facilitator of the Amani W group. Nalulwe and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Nalulwe and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Nalulwe takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and grow enough food to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Nalulwe had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Nalulwe was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Nalulwe will save for the future and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Amani W group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

Nalulwe is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Haykanush

texts.en: Haykanush is from the village of Arapy in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married and has a nine-year-old son.  Haykanush has a high school education and has been farming for the past ten years.  She is a hardworking person and would like to save enough money to renovate the family home.  Haykanush is looking for a loan to purchase livestock.  She expects this investment to increase the family income by 10%.  Arapy is a clean village with a good atmosphere for living and Haykanush enjoys living there.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Ufufuo Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Ufufuo SHG Group in Western Kenya! Elizabeth is the facilitator of the Ufufuo SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Elizabeth  takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Elizabeth had a very good maize yield harvesting 21 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Elizabeth was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Elizabeth  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Elizabeth will save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Ufufuo SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The picture shows Elizabeth and her group with the field officer far right.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Alvard

texts.en:
Alvard lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Gtashen.  She is the proud mother of three wonderful children: two daughters (19 and 21 years old) and a 20-year-old son.  Alvard works hard to support her family and also helps her close relatives.  She has a high school education and has been a farmer for 20 years.  She is looking for a loan to purchase seed, fertilizer, and fuel.  According to her business plan, this investment will increase her income by 20 percent.  She is pleased with the services of microfinance and the loan collection process.  Alvard’s capital investment in her business is five times her outstanding loans.



About the Field Partner – AREGAK Universal Credit Organization
In the fall of 1997, United Methodist Committee on Relief (UMCOR) established the AREGAK microfinance program, with the purpose to create economic opportunities for low income people who have no or limited access to the formal financial sources, especially in the remote rural areas. The microfinance program rapidly became one of the largest MFI in Armenia in terms of number of active clients and portfolio size.

In March of 2006, AREGAK UCO was registered as a Universal Credit Organization, structured as a Closed Joint Stock Company with UMCOR as the sole shareholder.
Today, AREGAK UCO provides a broad range of financial services to the population without compromising the social aspects of its mission and continues initiatives geared toward the fulfillment of its ethical principles

Vision Statement
To be the most dynamic and ethical financial institution in Armenia and Nagorno Karabagh.

Mission Statement
AREGAK supports the economic development of small and medium entrepreneurs with high quality, accessible and reliable financial services.

AREGAK UCO’s Ethical Principles
1. Integrity and Excellence
We deliver on our promises
We are honest and transparent in everything we do
We provide excellent customer service
2. Respect and Inclusion
Our leadership, workforce and decision-making reflect and respect the diversity of customers and communities we serve.
We value all employees, investing in their personal and professional growth.
3. Innovation
We develop new processes and systems to improve efficiency
We create value added new products to enhance economic opportunities

loans.use: to purchase seed, fertilizer, and fuel

loans.name: Sylvestre

texts.en: Sylvestre is 38 years old, married, and has six children between the ages of 5 and 18. He sells goods such as  beans, maize, etc. He has ten years of experience in his business and works from 7 a.m until 9 p.m every day except Saturday. Sylvestre currently employs three people to help him. Sylvestre has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand the inventory of his goods (beans, sorghum, and maize). With the profits, Sylvestre will reinvest in his business, pay school fees for his children, and save for his future.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of sorghum and beans.

loans.name: Antonine

texts.en: Antonine is married and blessed with three children who are in school. She describes herself as a hardworking business woman. For the last thirteen years, she has been selling sweets and biscuits to support her family. She also rents houses for more income. Her potential customers are the passersby. Antonine has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more sweets and biscuits for resale. In the next five years, she hopes to become more financially stable.

loans.use: to buy sweets and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Felimon

texts.en: Felimon is 36 years old and an industrious father and husband. He is a farmer who supports his family through his farming business. With this kind of occupation, he is able to provide for his family's basic necessities, but is not able to save money to improve his business. So, he is requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides. He hopes to make his business more secure with this loan and to earn enough extra income to improve his family's living situation.

loans.use: to purchase corn seeds, fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Haja

texts.en:
Haja, 31, lives in Caldwell. She is married and has two children,  9 and 13. They are in school and live at home.

For the past four years, she has been selling fresh fish in the local market. One of her main challenges is that the prices of fresh fish are high and sometimes there are not enough customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more fresh fish for her business.

She plans to save and build her house.

loans.use: to purchase more fresh fish for her business.

loans.name: Goharik

texts.en: Goharik lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Totosgyugh.  Totosgyugh is her birthplace and most of her relatives live close by.  Goharik is happily married with four children: three daughters (27, 30, and 33 years old) and a 21-year-old son.  She has a high school education and has been farming for the past 22 years.  She dreams that all her children will have happy, healthy lives.  Goharik has also been trying to save money to renovate the family home.  She is looking for a loan to purchase seeds.  Her investment should increase the family income by 20%.  She has invested her own capital in the business and wants to increase this investment.

loans.use: to purchase seeds

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en:
Jean Paul is 35 years old and married, with three children between the ages of 5 and 7. His business is well organized. He has a boutique where he sells cooking oil, rice, soap, sugar, salt, etc. Jean Paul has five years of experience and employs one person to help him.

Jean Paul has requested a loan from Kiva partner Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more cooking oil, rice, sugar, soap, and so on to sell. With the profits he earns as a result of this loan, Jean Paul will reinvest in his business and pay his children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil, rice, soap, and sugar, etc. for resale.

loans.name: Bolorkhorloo

texts.en:
Bolorkhorloo is a 29-year-old, hard-working woman who lives with her husband and children in the outer 'ger' (Mongolian yurt) district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her children, ages 3 and 5, attend local kindergarten while her husband works as a tractor-trailer driver at a local company. 

After working as a saleswoman for five years, Bolorkhorloo decided to start her own business in an indoor market called Tumen Plaza. She mostly sells women’s clothing imported from Beijing, China. As the market is located in a very busy shopping area, her business makes outstanding revenue. 

Bolorkhorloo is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) loan to import more clothes for the upcoming season because the New Year holiday is a high shopping season. She is a responsible client of our institution who repaid her previous loans successfully and on time. Bolor is working hard to improve her family’s living standards so her children can enjoy a safe and good quality of life as they grow.

loans.use: to import more clothes for the upcoming season.

loans.name: Angin

texts.en:
Angin is from the village of Isahakyan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She notes that the village was named after the famous Armenian writer Isahakyan, who was born there.  Angin is a trained nurse but due to difficult economic times, she has been farming for the past 20 years.  She has invested a substantial amount of her personal savings in the farm and is looking for a small loan.  With the loan, she will purchase animal feed.  This investment should increase the family income.  She is quite pleased with the services of microfinance and the crediting conditions.


About the Field Partner – AREGAK Universal Credit Organization
In the fall of 1997, United Methodist Committee on Relief (UMCOR) established the AREGAK microfinance program, with the purpose to create economic opportunities for low income people who have no or limited access to the formal financial sources, especially in the remote rural areas. The microfinance program rapidly became one of the largest MFI in Armenia in terms of number of active clients and portfolio size.

In March of 2006, AREGAK UCO was registered as a Universal Credit Organization, structured as a Closed Joint Stock Company with UMCOR as the sole shareholder.
Today, AREGAK UCO provides a broad range of financial services to the population without compromising the social aspects of its mission and continues initiatives geared toward the fulfillment of its ethical principles

Vision Statement
To be the most dynamic and ethical financial institution in Armenia and Nagorno Karabagh.

Mission Statement
AREGAK supports the economic development of small and medium entrepreneurs with high quality, accessible and reliable financial services.

AREGAK UCO’s Ethical Principles
1. Integrity and Excellence
We deliver on our promises
We are honest and transparent in everything we do
We provide excellent customer service
2. Respect and Inclusion
Our leadership, workforce and decision-making reflect and respect the diversity of customers and communities we serve.
We value all employees, investing in their personal and professional growth.
3. Innovation
We develop new processes and systems to improve efficiency
We create value added new products to enhance economic opportunities

loans.use: to purchase animal feed

loans.name: Enakhon

texts.ru: Энахон вдова, она целеустремленная и добросовестная женщина. Более 11 лет она занимается купле- продажей парфюмерии и разных игрушек. В этой сфере бизнеса она имеет богатый опыт, и знает свое дело. Она дарит всем хорошее настроение. Энахон хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить хорошую прибыль. Энахон запрашивает займ в размере 1000$ США для расширения бизнеса. Она надеется на вашу помощь и заранее благодарна вам за поддержку и доброту.
texts.en: Enakhon is a widow. She is a single-minded and conscientious woman. She has been buying and selling perfumes and various toys for more than eleven years. She has a wealth of experience and knows this business. Her good mood is contagious. Enakhon wants to expand her business and make a greater profit. Enakhon is asking for a loan of $1000 U.S. to expand her business. She looks forward to your help and thanks you in advance for your support and kindness.

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is married and blessed with an eight-year-old child who is in school. For the last seven years, he has been operating a motorbike transport business to support his family. He also practices dairy farming to supplement his income. Even though he runs his business in a very competitive environment, he has retained the business because of his good reputation. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business. Nicholas is requesting for a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a dairy cow.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Hussien

texts.en:
Hussien is a 52-year-old man. He is married with three sons and two daughters. He works in agriculture and raising poultry. 

Hussien wants to have his own project of raising broiler chickens to maximize his income.  He plans to purchase a large number of broilers to raise and resell, but he doesn't have enough money to buy them now. So, he needs to take a loan of $3,000 from FATEN. When Hussien gets the loan, he will pay to begin his project and purchase a large number of broilers to resell. One of his sons, who has good experience in this field, will help him succeed with this project. Hussien is shown in this photograph.

loans.use: to purchase broiler chickens.

loans.name: Salima's Group

texts.en:
Salima is married and has eight children. All of them are studying in a local school. It is very difficult for Salima and her husband to afford their living and educational expenses, which is why both Salima and her husband work.

Salima's husband is a mason, and Salima makes and sells decoration pieces. She receives orders from different gift shops in the market and completes their orders to earn income. She has a lot of passion for her work and she creates different designs and uses her skills very well in her work. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her business. With the loan investment, she will buy decoration  material like glitter, paint and brushes to make beautiful looking decoration pieces and also buys the decorations items likes (Vase, artificial flowers) etc. 

She is hopeful that she will be able to make beautiful looking decorative pieces and buy the decoration items in bulk that will be sold for higher profits. She is very experienced in her work and has been operating it for many years.

Note: In the group, one of the members has a clothing selling business, which is why they are holding clothes in the photo.

loans.use: to buy decoration material and decoration items

loans.name: Abdilat

texts.ru: Абдилат 57-летний фермер, живущий со своей семьей  селе Алике, что на юге Кыргызстана.  Абдилат работал водителем на автобазе, но зарплата не позволяла покрыть расходы семьи, и Абдилат решился на свой бизнес в животноводстве и полеводстве. Благодаря упорству и настойчивости Абдилата, начатое с суммы в 20,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство,  сегодня приносит около 20,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных  и мясных продуктов. Доходы от деятельности позволили Абдилату провести ремонт дома и провести свадьбы своих детей. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Абдилат обратился в компанию «Бай - Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку коров и баранов. Доходы от кредита Абдилат планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества домашние скотины.
texts.en: Abdilat is a 57 year-old farmer, living with his family in the Alike village in the south of Kyrgyzstan.  Abdilat used to work as a driver at an auto park, but his salary did not allow him to cover his family expenses, so he decided to open his own business of animal husbandry and farming.  Thanks to his persistence and hard work, Abdilat's business that started with 20,000 som (KGS), now brings in about 20,000 som (KGS) per month from the sales of dairy and meat products.  Earnings from the business allowed him to make repairs at home and hold weddings for his children.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, Abdilat requested a loan in the sum of 100,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase cattle and sheep.  He plans to invest the profits from this loan into further increasing livestock quantities.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and sheep

loans.name: Araksya

texts.en: Araksya is from the village of Pokr Mantash in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is a hardworking and honest person who has been engaged in farming for the past 15 years.  Araksya is happily married and has three children: two daughters (24 and 27 years old) and a 22-year-old son.  As her daughters are happily married, she is hoping for the same for her son.  Araksya is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  She expects her investment to increase the family income by 10%.  Her capital investment in the business will be six times her outstanding debt.  She is pleased with the services of microfinance, which has helped her family to continue living in Pokr Mantash.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a second-hand motorcycle for traveling back and forth to her workplace.

loans.name: Rachabgul

texts.ru: Рачабгул занимается торговлей тканей. Этим видом деятельности занимается восемнадцать лет. Ей 47 лет. Она замужем. У нее пятеро детей. Кредит берет для покупки тканей.
texts.en: Rachabgul is involved in selling fabrics.  She has been in this business for eighteen years.  Rachabgul is 47 years old, married and has five children.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of fabrics.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is from the village of Amasia in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with two children: a 14-year-old son and a 12-year-old daughter.  She is a trained nurse and has been engaged in farming for around 20 years.  She dreams for her children to attend and graduate from college.  Alla is looking for a loan to purchase livestock.  With this investment, her family income will increase by 20%.  The capital she has invested in her business is around four times her outstanding liabilities.  She enjoys living in Amasia and the ability to have access to financing.


About the Field Partner – AREGAK Universal Credit Organization

In the fall of 1997, United Methodist Committee on Relief (UMCOR) established the AREGAK microfinance program, with the purpose to create economic opportunities for low income people who have no or limited access to the formal financial sources, especially in the remote rural areas. The microfinance program rapidly became one of the largest MFI in Armenia in terms of number of active clients and portfolio size.
In March of 2006, AREGAK UCO was registered as a Universal Credit Organization, structured as a Closed Joint Stock Company with UMCOR as the sole shareholder.
Today, AREGAK UCO provides a broad range of financial services to the population without compromising the social aspects of its mission and continues initiatives geared toward the fulfillment of its ethical principles

Vision Statement

To be the most dynamic and ethical financial institution in Armenia and Nagorno Karabagh.

Mission Statement

AREGAK supports the economic development of small and medium entrepreneurs with high quality, accessible and reliable financial services.

AREGAK UCO’s Ethical Principles

1. Integrity and Excellence
We deliver on our promises
We are honest and transparent in everything we do
We provide excellent customer service

2. Respect and Inclusion
Our leadership, workforce and decision-making reflect and respect the diversity of customers and communities we serve. 
We value all employees, investing in their personal and professional growth. 

3. Innovation
We develop new processes and systems to improve efficiency
We create value added new products to enhance economic opportunities

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Arevhat

texts.en: Arevhat lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Pokr Mantash.  She is married and has a 32-year-old son.  She considers herself a hardworking and honest person and has been able to run the family farm for the past 20 years.  In addition to supporting her family, she helps relatives nearby with produce grown on the farm.  Arevhat would like her grandchildren to receive a university education.  She is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  According to her business plan, this investment will increase her income by 15%.  Arevhat’s capital investment in the farm is around six times more than her outstanding debt.  She is pleased with the services of microfinance and the services provided in Pokr Mantash.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Musyoka

texts.en: Musyoka is a 28-year-old married man. He has been distributing bread to retail shops to earn a living. He also practices poultry farming to earn extra income. He has employed two people to assist him in his business. He has managed to improve his business because he has been trained in good business management through Faulu Kenya.  He is requesting a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to buy chickens.

loans.use: to buy chickens.

loans.name: Bakhtiyor

texts.ru: Бахтиёр женат и ответственный отец двоих детей. Он имеет медицинское образование и является владельцем небольшой аптеки. Его аптека находится в доступном и удобном месте которая доступна всем пользователям. Бахтиёр хочет приобрести новые  лекарства для того,  чтобы доставить своим клиентам медикаменты своевременно. С этой целью он запрашивает займ в размере 2000$ США. Он надеется на вашу помощь и заранее благодарен вам за ваше понимание.
texts.en: Bakhtiyor is married and is a responsible father of two children.  He has a medical education and is an owner of a small pharmacy.  His pharmacy is located in an accessible and convenient location, which is reachable for all customers.  Bakhtiyor wants to purchase new medicines, so that he can provide medicines to his customers in a timely manner.  This is why he is requesting a loan in the sum of $2000.  He hopes to get your help and is grateful to you in advance for your understanding.

loans.use: to purchase medicines

loans.name: Titus

texts.en: Titus is a hardworking 42-year-old businessman. He is married and blessed with five children who are in school. He has been selling clothes for the last ten years to support his family. He also practices farming to supplement his income. His potential customers are passerby. Titus is requesting a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy jackets, trousers and shirts for resale.  In the next 5 years, he plans to establish a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy jackets, trousers and shirts for resale.

loans.name: Dibirmagamed

texts.en:
Dibirmagamed is a 54-year-old farmer from the village of Chantlikure, East Georgia. He is married and lives with his family: wife – Sikinat, two sons (23 and 22 years old) and a daughter-in-law. All family members are involved in the family agricultural business, which is their only source of income. 
They have milk cows and sell homemade cheese. Also the family owns a plot of land, where various fruits and vegetables are grown. Harvested products are sold locally and the family's total average monthly income is 500 Laris. 

Dibirmagamed requested credit to purchase materials for greenhouse construction. He will grow vegetables in the winter months and sell them in the spring for seasonally high prices, which will significantly increase the family's income. 
The greenhouse will also be used for growing vegetables in the summer months. Dibirmagamed plans to reinvest any increase in income in the further development of the family dairy farm; he plans to purchase milk cows.

loans.use: to purchase materials for greenhouse construction

loans.name: Jaribu Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Jaribu Group in Western Kenya! Jacklyn is the facilitator of the Jaribu group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jacklyn  takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jacklyn had a good maize yield harvesting 23 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jacklyn was only able to harvest 12 1/2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jacklyn  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Jacklyn will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Jaribu group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer is a focused 31-year-old businesswoman. She is married and blessed with two children who are in school. She has been running a grocery business for the last three years to support her family. Her potential customers are local residents and passerby. She has employed one person to assist her in managing the business. In the next 5 years, she plans to establish a wholesale operation. Jennifer is requesting a loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings to buy onions, vegetables and fruits for resale. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has been able to adopt the culture of saving.

loans.use: To buy onions, vegetables and fruits to sell.

loans.name: Amani Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Amani Group in Western Kenya! Ezekiel is the facilitator of the Amani SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Ezekiel takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Ezekiel had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Ezekiel was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ezekiel and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Ezekiel will educate his children and expand his farmland.

In 2012, the members of Amani SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Ezekiel with his group members and the field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lucila

texts.en:
This is Lucila, 63, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Angel, a butcher and father to their children. Together they work hard for a safe and secure future for  their family.

Lucila operates a variety store. In the Philippines. A variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lucila hopes that her business will continue to be successful, just as she fervently hopes that her children will be able to finish their studies. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Kikundi Cha Kilimo Liyombo Group

texts.en:
Adolfu is a 32-year-old married man with three children. He has worked in agricultural for over six years. His main economic activity is growing coffee, maize and beans. Adolfu earns a low income that leads to his failure to purchase fertilizers, hoes, insecticides and gumboots. 

Adolfu seeks working capital to buy fertilizers, hoes, insecticides and gumboots. He believes that in five years to come his coffee, maize and beans production will increase from 5 acres to 10 acres and he will be able to buy a power tiller for cultivation, to buy a transport vehicle and own an insecticides pump machine.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, hoes, insectisides and gumboots

loans.name: Teta

texts.en: Teta, a 28-year-old married mother of four-year-old twins, both in school, lives in Caldwell where, for the past two years, she has been selling slippers and cosmetics in the local market. One of her main challenges is the high cost of slippers and cosmetics. Teta is now requesting a loan to purchase more of these products, and plans to build her house and attend college in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase  more slippers and cosmetics  for her business.

loans.name: Fayzamad

texts.ru: Файзамад проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 50 лет. Он женат. У него пятеро детей. Он имеет среднее образование. Предоставляет услугу, перерабатывает хлопок. В этой области он пять лет. Кредит берет для приобретения нового оборудования.
texts.en: Fayzamad lives in the city of Kulob.  He is 50 years old, married and has five children.  He has a secondary education.  Fayzamad provides a service of processing cotton.  He has been in this business for five years.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of new equipment.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment

loans.name: Levan

texts.en:
Levan is a 62-year-old farmer from the village of Babaneuri, Kakheti Region, East Georgia. He lives alone. His source of income is an agricultural business. In particular, he has two milk cows and three calves. Levan produces cheese and sells it to local retailers.

Also, he has two hectares of land where he grows maize. Levan sells the maize in the local market. His total average monthly income is 800 Laris.

Levan requested a loan for purchasing calves. He will grow the calves and when they start milking, he will be able to produce more cheese. This will increase Levan’s income, which he will use for improving his living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase calves for expansion of his dairy farm.

loans.name: Askaraly

texts.ru: Аскарали 45 лет, женат, воспитывает троих детей.  В поисках средств дохода для своей семьи, в 2001 году Аскарали начал свой бизнес в откорме и перепродаже скота. Благодаря упорству и настойчивости Аскарали, начатое с суммы в 13,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство,  сегодня приносит около 8,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных  и мясных продуктов. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Аскарали обратился в компанию «Бай - Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 30,000 сом (KGS) на покупку баранов. Доходы от кредита Аскарали планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества домашней скотины.
texts.en: Askaraly is 45 years old, married and is raising three children.  In search of a source of income for his family, Askaraly started his own business of fattening up and reselling livestock in 2011.  Thanks to his hard work and persistence, his business that was started with 13,000 som (KGS) brings in about 8,000 som (KGS) per month now from sales of dairy and meat products.  In order to further increase his livestock headcount, Askaraly requested a loan in the sum of 30,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase sheep.  He plans to invest the profits from the loan into increasing livestock quantities further.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente is 36 years of age and is a farmer in the village. He has four children and he provides for their needs. To meet their demands, he is working hard in his business to yield enough profit. 

He is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase needed farm inputs such as corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides. 

He is working hard for the improvement of his family’s lifestyle as well as to secure the future of his children.

loans.use: to purchase needed farm inputs such as corn seeds, fertilizers, and  pesticides.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel, 34, is married and has four children. She lives in Lopoc, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte.

Maricel owns a sari2x store to earn a living. She has requested a loan of PHP 20,000 to purchase more stock to sell.

Maricel has been a member of PMPC for more than one year. In the future, Maricel hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell/buy groceries to sell/retail

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase high grade manure to improve his tea farms.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace has practiced poultry farming in Naivasha town for the last 12 years.  She is 34 years old, married to James, and they have two school-going children.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan to buy more chickens so as to boost her poultry business. Anticipating the festive season, this will also enable her to distribute chicken and eggs to the big hotels both inside and outside of Naivasha town. In the future, Grace hopes to become one of the leading large scale poultry farmers in Naivasha town.

loans.use: to buy more chickens.

loans.name: Lani

texts.en:
This is Lani, who is 47 and a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Edgar, a vendor, and she is a mother to their four children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lani operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and resells it with a little profit. Her products are plastic tent roofing and other similar products. She attracts customers by offering low prices and many options. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy plastic roofing products and other items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lani hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and dreams of providing her children a bright future. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of plastic roofing products needed in her business.

loans.name: Potenciana

texts.en:
Potenciana is married with six children. She is 44 years old and lives in Buenavista, Pagadian City, Philippines.

She has a business a cow raising just to earn a living. She also had a pig dispersal business. She has been doing this for 5 years.She earn 5000 each month from this activity. She has requested a loan of 20000 to  purchase cows for her business.

She has been a member of PMPC for 5 years. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase cows for her business

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
This is Amelita, who is 47 and a resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Roberto and is a mother to her two children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 
 
Amelita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and reselling them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 22,000. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Amelita dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have her own grocery store. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which  she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mikheil

texts.en:
Mikheil is 29 years old. He lives in the village Matani, East Georgia, with his family: wife Lela and his 2 years old daughter. Mikheil and Lela have a small rabbit-breeding farm. They sell rabbits in the village. Along with the farm, they own small grocery store in the village, located in their yard. Mikheil and Lela purchase grocery products on wholesale market and sell them in their store. Total average monthly income of the family is 900 Laris.

Mikheil requested credit for expansion of the rabbit-breeding farm. He will purchase additional pure-strain rabbits for the farm. After the domestic animals start breeding Mikheil will have more rabbits for sale. It will increase family’s income. Mikheil and Lela plan to use increased income for renovation of their house, as it is old and already in bed conditions.

loans.use: to purchase pure-strain rabbits for expansion of the rabbit farm.

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en:
Fatmeh is a 60-year-old married lady who has four sons and daughters. She is married to Mohammad who works as a land broker.

Fatmeh is known for her delicious bread called Shrak. It is commonly used to make Shawerma sandwiches and other food dishes. Her friends used to ask her to make them some bread, so she thought of turning it into a business five years ago. She started selling by the kilo to neighbors and friends.

Recently she expanded her services and started to make larger quantities and distribute to the food shops and cafeterias. Now she has more orders than she can keep up with because of her old Saj, which is used to bake the shrak. Therefore, she applied for a loan in order to buy a new Saj and a new oven to help increase her productivity.

loans.use: To buy a new bakery oven

loans.name: Saymumin

texts.ru: Саймумин занимается разведением крупнорогатого скота. В этой области он десять лет. Ему 43 года. Он женат. У него семеро детей. Он имеет средне – специальное образование, сварщик по специальности. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы.
texts.en: Saymumin breeds large horned cattle. He has been in this business for ten years. He is 43 years old, married and has seven children. He has specialized secondary education in the field of welding. Saymumin is taking out the loan to buy a milk cow.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow.

loans.name: Diestoria

texts.en:
This is Diestoria, who is 40 and a resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Mario, a seaman, and she is mother to their children, who already have their own families. She manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Diestoria operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers and resells it with a little profit. Her products are ready-to-wear clothes and other similar products. She attracts customers with low prices and by offering many options.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 47,000. She will use the loan to buy ready-to-wear clothes and other items to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
